A WRONG IMPRESSION
From the intensity of fraternity rushing as it has been conducted on the campus during the past few weeks it seems likely
that every freshman who is at all interested, or is aware of the
annual scramble, has received the impression that fraternities
are the only important feature of undergraduate life, and the one
standard by which a man is judged by his fellows. We wish, if
possible, to correct this impression.
We are in favor of fraternities. They have a definite place
on the campus, and a great many benefits may be derived from
them. They are not, however, as all-important as they seem to
freshmen at this time of year, especially to those who have not
been noticed. On the part of these men there is far too often a
feeling that they are missing all opportunity for .fellowship, and
that in some manner they have been judged and found wanting.
Nothing could be more untrue, but the prevalence of this belief
is one of the most unfortunate of American college life.
Class organization and activities present opportunities for
some of the firmest friendships of college. The second belief,
which carries the worst sting, that failing to make a fraternity
implies failure to measure up to undergraduate standards is
equally unfounded. The fact that every chapter has an individual policy, and that one dissenting vote will bar a candidate,
though the other members favor him, is sufficient to dispel this
idea. Many fine and popular men at Hopkins have not belonged
to fraternities.
If men who are being overlooked at this time will bear two
things in mind, the problem will be greatly simplified. First, that
fraternities should be viewed as groups of friends, with different
policies and standards, and not as judges to pass on a man's
worthiness or unworthiness. Second, that rushing is done of
necessity quite hurriedly, so that the man who has not yet been
notified will have a large chance in the next year or so of being
discovered by the group into 'which he fits best.

Continuing our theme of last week, we beg your indulgence
while we say another word or two concerning that blushing, rushing, mushing, and gushing specimen of humanity—the coed.
*
*
When we -were drafted into the service, we made the editor
promise that our copy would never see the cruel cold visage of
the blue pencil. This he did very reluctantly, for though our identity must of necessity be hidden from you, dearest reader, he was
a bit afraid of our Bolshevistic propensities, as you would be, too,
if you should ever discover who we are. Don't fret, however,
we aren't the kind of Bolshevik that is likely to put a bomb under
a table in the Tudor-Stuart room or the Military Office, but rather
the Broadus Mitchell type, whose ideas are grand and slightly
impractical, but who means no harm.
*
*
But to return to the girls. Frankly, having visited (no, not
attended) the Universities of California, Chicago, and Cornell,
we believe that co-education is a great institution if it be real coeducation. At the colleges mentioned the co-eds conduct themselves like college students, and synchronize perfectly with (make
dates with) the male students. Also, they know their place!
Here, however,—well, we'll leave it up to you.
*
*
You know, when the College for Teachers was incorporated
into the University, it was just what its name would lead you
to believe—a college for teachers. The classes were composed
principally of women teaching in local high schools who wanted
to obtain the benefits (Hurrah!) of a college education though
they were actually somewhat past the collegiate age. Accordingly, afternoon and night classes were instituted.
*'
Little did the proponents of the scheme dream that their
altruistic motives would, in naughty 1926, be thwarted by the
admittance to the "Teachers' College" o- f painted, rouged, sweet;
bold young things who sauntered up and down the hitherto
austere pathways of the quadrangle, distracting the attention of
the R. 0. T. C. from its drill masters! Hardly did they visualize the flashing of knees as one of the "students" scampered down
the hall to a four o'clock class!
Now, instead of carrying on the roll books the names of
partly decayed forty-five year old schoolmarms, the C. for T. is
full of flighty flappers from not only Baltimore city, but also
from such far away places as Towson and New York.
And now we have the advent of the educated flapper! Imagine some unsuspecting freshman making a date with a coed
and finding himself being expected to hash out with his sweetie
the intricacies of Flemish art or advanced Chinese literature.
Instead of begging to go to a movie, she will want him to take
her to a class in thermodynamics.
You, fair reader, may be prone to take all of this rather
lightly, but we really feel apprehensive.
Instead of raising the standard of secondary school education in the leading city of the Free State, the Board of Trustees
(or whoever was responsible for the growth of the College for
Trenchers) has provided a haven for naughty girlies endowed
with a spark of erudite ambition. And take it from us (we
wanted to say "me," but we dared not) they've made a heaven
of their haven!
There's still some hope, though! No co-eds were on the
.Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration programme.

Of the many results the Half Century Celebration is expected or hoped to accomplish, local newspaper publicity for Hopkins has probably never been advanced as one. Publicity in the
press has of course been considered as a necessary means of advertising the event and arousing interest, but never as an end
in itself. The avowed aims of the movement, of which the Anniversary is a step, will probably be infinitely more far-reaching and
important, but the phase we mentioned has set us to thinking that
it deserves some attention.
During the past week, the Baltimore papers have been filled
with news articles and special features concerning the celebration
itself and the University as a whole. Although these articles have
appeared only on account of the Anniversary, and are purely incidental to its plans, the fact remains that .for the first time in

many years, Hopkins is being brought prominently to the attention of Baltimoreans.
The city has always taken Hopkins largely as a matter of
course. In the papers, for instance, outside of accounts of wholesome but asinine-appearing pursuits like class battles and banquet seasons, and a few incomplete and rather sensational articles last year on the New Plan, Hopkins does not figure very
largely.
Naturally, the recent deluge of publicity will cease, in fact,
has ceased; but the interest which has been aroused should not
wane altogether. If Baltimore can be kept alive to the real life
of the University, there may be interesting developments.

today.

held, and Rabbi Israel answered
all questions asked by the members.

A WRONG IMPRESSION
From the intensity of fraternity rushing as it has been conducted on the campus during the past few weeks it seems likely
that every freshman who is at all interested, or is aware of the
annual scramble, has received the impression that fraternities
are the only important feature of undergraduate life, and the one
standard by which a man is judged by his fellows. We wish, if
possible, to correct this impression.
We are in favor of fraternities. They have a definite place
on the campus, and a great many benefits may be derived from
them. They are not, however, as all-important as they seem to
freshmen at this time of year, especially to those who have not
been noticed. On the part of these men there is far too often a
feeling that they are missing all opportunity for .fellowship, and
that in some manner they have been judged and found wanting.
Nothing could be more untrue, but the prevalence of this belief
is one of the most unfortunate of American college life.
Class organization and activities present opportunities for
some of the firmest friendships of college. The second belief,
which carries the worst sting, that failing to make a fraternity
implies failure to measure up to undergraduate standards is
equally unfounded. The fact that every chapter has an individual policy, and that one dissenting vote will bar a candidate,
though the other members favor him, is sufficient to dispel this
idea. Many fine and popular men at Hopkins have not belonged
to fraternities.
If men who are being overlooked at this time will bear two
things in mind, the problem will be greatly simplified. First, that
fraternities should be viewed as groups of friends, with different
policies and standards, and not as judges to pass on a man's
worthiness or unworthiness. Second, that rushing is done of
necessity quite hurriedly, so that the man who has not yet been
notified will have a large chance in the next year or so of being
discovered by the group into 'which he fits best.
